raw_text:
Straw to attend Auschwitz service
 
 Foreign Secretary Jack Straw will visit Auschwitz for the 60th anniversary of the former Nazi concentration camp's liberation, it has been announced.
 
 Prince Edward will also join the UK delegation in Poland for National Holocaust Memorial Day on 27 January. Between 1.1 and 1.5 million people, mainly Jews, were killed at Auschwitz. The Tories said they were glad Mr Straw had been "shamed" into going, having earlier criticised the decision to send a lower-ranking official. Shadow Foreign Secretary Michael Ancram said: "I am glad the foreign secretary has finally been shamed into representing Britain at this important act of commemoration. "Once again this government has shown crass insensitivity until it has been forced by public opinion into doing what it should have done in the first place."
 
 In Britain, the Queen and Prince Philip will lead the nation's commemoration at a service in Westminster Hall, London. The Queen will also host a reception for holocaust survivors at St James's Palace. Altogether, some six million people, mainly Jews, perished in the Holocaust. The Queen's grandson, Prince Harry, sparked outrage earlier this week after photographs of him wearing a Nazi uniform at a costume party emerged. The prince, 20, apologised, but critics have called for him to go to Auschwitz for the commemoration of the Soviets' 1945 liberation of the camp. Prince Harry should see for himself "the results of the hated symbol he so foolishly and brazenly chose to wear", Rabbi Marvin Hier, founder of Jewish human rights group the Simon Wiesenthal Center said.
llama3.2:1b: Foreign Secretary Jack Straw will attend an Auschwitz service on 1 February; Prince Edward will join the UK delegation in Poland for National Holocaust Memorial Day.
The Queen will lead a commemoration service in Westminster Hall with Prince Philip and host a reception for holocaust survivors at St James's Palace.
Auschwitz was established to hold approximately 1.1 million people, mainly Jews, from 1940-45.
Jack Straw faced criticism earlier for refusing to attend the Auschwitz service, while Michael Ancram said he was "shamed" into doing so after public pressure.
llama3.2:3b: Foreign Secretary Jack Straw will visit Auschwitz for the 60th anniversary of its liberation to attend a service, along with Prince Edward.

The Queen and Prince Philip will also hold a memorial service in Westminster Hall, London, while Prince Harry is expected to visit Auschwitz despite criticism over wearing a Nazi uniform at a costume party.

Prince Edward will join the UK delegation in Poland on National Holocaust Memorial Day, with more than one million people killed at Auschwitz.
The Tories criticized Mr Straw's decision to go, saying they were "shamed" into representing Britain at this important commemoration.
The Queen and Prince Philip will lead the nation’s commemoration service at Westminster Hall, while Prince Harry apologized for wearing a Nazi uniform during a costume party.
Rabbi Marvin Hier said Prince Harry should see for himself how Auschwitz affects him.
